DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Dispatched to Panama From N.C., California
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers from the Rapid Deployment Force at Fort Ord and from Fort Bragg, N.C., have been dispatched to Panama to help apprehend Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Sen. Pete Wilson said today. ``Elements of the 7th Light Infantry Division ... have supplemented the 12,000 troops already in Panama,'' the California Republican said in a telephone interview with Los Angeles radio station KNX. Troops from Fort Bragg were airlifted to Panama, said Wilson, who praised President George Bush for the decision to send to the Central American country. Noriega is ``up to his eyeballs in the drug traffic,'' Wilson said. Noriega, who nullified his country's May elections, was indicted on U.S. drug trafficking charges in February 1988. The senator's comments followed the mobilization Tuesday night of an undetermined number of soliders from Fort Ord, about 80 miles south of San Francisco, and their transfer, apparently to Travis Air Force Base in Fairfield. Soldiers of the 7th Infantry Division (Light), which in some deployments includes artillery and aviation units, were ordered to report to Fort Ord for an ``emergency deployment readiness training exercise,'' some time Monday, said Jim Davis, public affairs officers for the Army. Davis, however, said that as a matter of policy, he could not comment on the number mobilized, their destination or their time of departure. By early today, military convoys were seen heading north on Interstate 680 toward Fairfield, according to the California Highway Patrol. Nineteen buses and a truck loaded with soldiers arrived at Travis late Tuesday, according KCRA-TV in Sacramento. More buses and trucks were reported going into the base about 40 miles northeast of San Francisco. But a base spokesman said he could not say where the soliders came from or where they were going. ``We cannot comment on any military operations at this time,'' said Sgt. Jerry Taranto. ``We can't comment on anything on the operation.'' Travis was enveloped in heavy fog, making flights difficult. Earlier Tuesday, C-141 planes were seen in the air around Fort Bragg, home of the Army's 82nd Airborne division. Fort Bragg spokesmen would say only that Army units there were participating in a routine ``emergency deployment readiness exercise.'' Sgt. Bobby Feibel, a spokesman for the division, said he had no information on reports that some of the division had left Fort Bragg.
